_header: Bachus which is god of the glad vine
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 235.
_description: John Lydgate, A Mumming at Eltham — twelve stanzas rhyme royal including Envoy and alternating refrains: ‘Pees with your leges plente and gladness’ and ‘Ay by encresse Ioye gladness of harte’

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Bachus which is god of þe glade vyneIuno and Ceres acorded
                    alle þeos threeThorughe þeyre power which þat is
                    devyneSende nowe þeyre gifftes vn to your magestee…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…To you pryncesse al so yif yee aduerteAy be encresse Ioye
                    gladdnesse of herte
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Loo here begynneþe a balade made by daun John Lidegate at Eltham in
                    Cristmasse for a momyng to fore þe Kyng and þe Qwene (p. 37); þe
                    maner of a moumynge To fore þe Kynge at Elthame (RT)
CamTCC600.Editions:
Brotanek,  Rudolph. 
             Die Englischen Maskenspiele.
         Vienna, Leipzig: W. Braumüller, 1902: 306-8.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Bachus which is god of the glade vyneIuno and Ceres accorded all
                    thes thre…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…to you pryncesse also yff ye aduerteAy by encresse Ioye
                    gladnesse of harte
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
Loo here begenneth a balade made by dan Iohn Lidgate at elltham in
                    cristmasse ffor a momyng to fore the kynge and the Qwene (f. 135v, by
